title: 106_s148
content:
The Act is titled the "Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act". Congress finds that approximately 500 bird species in the United States migrate among countries, with many neotropical migratory bird populations in decline due to habitat loss and degradation. Neotropical migratory birds require international cooperation for conservation efforts along their migration routes. Initiatives to conserve these birds and their habitat can be strengthened through increased coordination. The purposes of this Act are to perpetuate healthy populations of neotropical migratory birds, support conservation initiatives in the United States, Latin America, and the Caribbean, and provide financial resources for international cooperation. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS.

    In this Act:
        (1) Account.--The term ``Account'' means the Neotropical 
    Migratory Bird Conservation Account established by section 9(a).
        (2) Conservation.--The term ``conservation'' means methods necessary to ensure the long-term viability of neotropical migratory bird species, including protection, management, habitat maintenance, research, law enforcement, and community outreach.
        (3) Secretary.--The term ``Secretary'' means the Secretary of 
    the Interior. The Secretary will establish a program to provide financial assistance for projects promoting the conservation of neotropical migratory birds. Project proposals can be submitted by various entities, including individuals, government agencies, and international organizations. To be eligible for financial assistance under this Act, applicants must submit a project proposal that includes the responsible individual's name, project purposes, qualifications of project personnel, estimated funds and time needed, sources of matching funds, and a focus on conserving neotropical migratory bird species. The proposal should also outline mechanisms for local public participation in project development and implementation. The project proposal must include consultation with wildlife authorities, sensitivity to local resources, promotion of bird conservation, and necessary information for evaluation. Recipients must submit periodic reports for project progress evaluation. The Federal share of project costs should not exceed 25%. Non-Federal share must not come from Federal grant programs and can be paid in cash for projects in the US or in cash/in kind for projects in foreign countries. The Secretary's duties under the Act include developing guidelines for project proposals, encouraging submissions from wildlife management authorities, selecting proposals that meet requirements and conservation needs, and implementing the Act. Cooperation is also emphasized. The Secretary shall support and coordinate efforts to conserve neotropical migratory bird species by facilitating meetings, exchanging information, entering agreements, and coordinating activities with existing conservation projects. An advisory group may be convened to assist in carrying out the Act. The Secretary may convene an advisory group of individuals involved in neotropical migratory bird conservation. The group must hold open meetings, provide public notice, and keep minutes available. The group is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The advisory group for neotropical migratory bird conservation is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. SEC. 8. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress by October 1, 2002, on the program's results and effectiveness under this Act, with recommendations for improvements and whether the program should continue. SEC. 9. NEOTROPICAL MIGRATORY BIRD CONSERVATION ACCOUNT. Establishment of the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account within the Multinational Species Conservation Fund of the Treasury to receive donations and appropriations for conservation purposes. The Secretary of the Treasury can use the funds in the Account to carry out conservation activities, with a limit on administrative expenses. The Secretary may use up to 3 percent or $80,000 for administrative expenses under this Act and can accept donations for the same purpose. Donations received will be transferred to the Treasury for deposit into the Account. Authorization of appropriations for the Account to carry out the Act is set at $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2005, with at least 75 percent to be used for projects outside the United States.
